message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest allergic rhinitis, which is caused by an IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction. Atopic dermatitis also involves IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reactions, making it the most similar disease in terms of pathophysiology. Allergic contact dermatitis and irritant contact dermatitis involve a different immune response, and systemic lupus erythematosus is an autoimmune disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of allergic rhinitis, which is caused by an allergic reaction to environmental triggers such as pollen. Atopic dermatitis is also caused by an allergic reaction and shares similar pathophysiology. Allergic contact dermatitis, irritant contact dermatitis, and systemic lupus erythematosus have different pathophysiologies and are not as closely related to allergic rhinitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described by the patient suggest seasonal allergies, which have a similar pathophysiology to atopic dermatitis. Allergic contact dermatitis and irritant contact dermatitis are skin conditions that involve direct exposure to irritants or allergens, while systemic lupus erythematosus is an autoimmune disease with a different pathophysiology.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described by the patient, including the seasonal nature of the symptoms and a family history of asthma, suggest allergic rhinitis, which has a similar pathophysiology to atopic dermatitis. Allergic contact dermatitis and irritant contact dermatitis are forms of skin inflammation caused by exposure to allergens or irritants, respectively, and systemic lupus erythematosus is an autoimmune disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest a seasonal allergy, which is related to Type I hypersensitivity reactions. Atopic dermatitis has a similar pathophysiology as it is also a Type I hypersensitivity reaction with involvement of IgE antibodies. Allergic contact dermatitis and irritant contact dermatitis involve Type IV hypersensitivity reactions, while systemic lupus erythematosus is an autoimmune disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described by the patient point towards allergic rhinitis, and among the options, the disease with similar pathophysiology is Atopic dermatitis. Both allergies and atopic dermatitis involve the immune system's hypersensitivity reactions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with allergic rhinitis, which has a similar pathophysiology with atopic dermatitis. Both conditions involve a type I hypersensitivity reaction mediated by IgE antibodies. Allergic contact dermatitis and irritant contact dermatitis are caused by direct contact with an allergen or irritant, respectively. Systemic lupus erythematosus is an autoimmune disease that does not involve type I hypersensitivity reaction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are suggestive of allergic rhinitis, which has a similar pathophysiology to atopic dermatitis, both being part of the atopic triad along with asthma. Allergic contact dermatitis and irritant contact dermatitis can cause skin inflammation and rash, while systemic lupus erythematosus is an autoimmune disease that affects many organs, but not the respiratory system in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest allergic rhinitis, which has a similar pathophysiology to atopic dermatitis (eczema). Both conditions involves an overreaction of the body's immune system to a specific allergen trigger. Allergic contact dermatitis and irritant contact dermatitis are unrelated conditions. Systemic lupus erythematosus is an autoimmune disease and also unrelated to the symptoms presented.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest seasonal allergic rhinitis, which has a similar pathophysiology to atopic dermatitis. Both are caused by an overactive immune response to allergens. Allergic contact dermatitis is caused by exposure to a specific allergen, while irritant contact dermatitis is caused by exposure to a non-allergen irritant. Systemic lupus erythematosus is an autoimmune disease with a different pathophysiology.
